a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. sin x + sin (2*x) + sin (3*x) + sin (4*x) + sin (5*x) + sin (6*x) + sin (7*x) + sin (8*x) = cos (5*x) * cos (10*x) * cos (20*x)"
shows  "sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80 = 4 * sqrt 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\frac{\sin 10^\circ + \sin 20^\circ + \sin 30^\circ + \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ + \sin 60^\circ + \sin 70^\circ + \sin 80^\circ}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\] The final Answer is 4 \sqrt{2}
 ### Proof
 By sum-to-product, \begin{align} \sin 10^\circ + \sin 80^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 35^\circ, \\ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 70^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 25^\circ, \\ \sin 30^\circ + \sin 60^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\
 \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the given expression becomes \[\frac{2 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 35^\circ + \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ + \cos 5^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\]Similarly, \begin{align}
 \cos 35^\circ + \cos 5^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\ \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the expression becomes \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ \cos 20^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ} = \frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ}.\]Finally, $\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ = 2 \cos 10^\circ \cos 5^\circ,$ so
 \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ} = 8 \sin 45^\circ = \boxed{4 \sqrt{2}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. sin x + sin (2*x) + sin (3*x) + sin (4*x) + sin (5*x) + sin (6*x) + sin (7*x) + sin (8*x) = cos (5*x) * cos (10*x) * cos (20*x)"
shows  "sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80 = 4 * sqrt 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that the sum of the sine of multiples of 10 up to 80 is equal to the product of the cosine of multiples of 5, 10, and 20, find the numerical value of this sum. The final answer is $4 \sqrt{2}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. sin x + cos x = 1"
shows  "(sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80) / (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20) = 4 * sqrt 2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\frac{\sin 10^\circ + \sin 20^\circ + \sin 30^\circ + \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ + \sin 60^\circ + \sin 70^\circ + \sin 80^\circ}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\] The final Answer is 4 \sqrt{2}
 ### Proof
 By sum-to-product, \begin{align} \sin 10^\circ + \sin 80^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 35^\circ, \\ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 70^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 25^\circ, \\ \sin 30^\circ + \sin 60^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\
 \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the given expression becomes \[\frac{2 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 35^\circ + \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ + \cos 5^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\]Similarly, \begin{align}
 \cos 35^\circ + \cos 5^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\ \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the expression becomes \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ \cos 20^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ} = \frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ}.\]Finally, $\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ = 2 \cos 10^\circ \cos 5^\circ,$ so
 \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ} = 8 \sin 45^\circ = \boxed{4 \sqrt{2}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. sin x + cos x = 1"
shows  "(sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80) / (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20) = 4 * sqrt 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given that for all $x$, $\sin x + \cos x = 1$, find the value of the expression $\frac{\sin 10 + \sin 20 + \sin 30 + \sin 40 + \sin 50 + \sin 60 + \sin 70 + \sin 80}{\cos 5 \cdot \cos 10 \cdot \cos 20}$. The final answer is $4\sqrt{2}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. sin x + sin (2*x) + sin (3*x) + sin (4*x) + sin (5*x) + sin (6*x) + sin (7*x) + sin (8*x) = 4 * sqrt 2 * cos (5 * x) * cos (10 * x) * cos (20 * x)"
shows  "\<forall> x. sin (x/10) + sin (x/5) + sin (3*x/10) + sin (2*x/5) + sin (x/2) + sin (3*x/5) + sin (7*x/10) + sin (4*x/5) = 4 * sqrt 2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\frac{\sin 10^\circ + \sin 20^\circ + \sin 30^\circ + \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ + \sin 60^\circ + \sin 70^\circ + \sin 80^\circ}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\] The final Answer is 4 \sqrt{2}
 ### Proof
 By sum-to-product, \begin{align} \sin 10^\circ + \sin 80^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 35^\circ, \\ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 70^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 25^\circ, \\ \sin 30^\circ + \sin 60^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\
 \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the given expression becomes \[\frac{2 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 35^\circ + \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ + \cos 5^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\]Similarly, \begin{align}
 \cos 35^\circ + \cos 5^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\ \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the expression becomes \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ \cos 20^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ} = \frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ}.\]Finally, $\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ = 2 \cos 10^\circ \cos 5^\circ,$ so
 \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ} = 8 \sin 45^\circ = \boxed{4 \sqrt{2}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. sin x + sin (2*x) + sin (3*x) + sin (4*x) + sin (5*x) + sin (6*x) + sin (7*x) + sin (8*x) = 4 * sqrt 2 * cos (5 * x) * cos (10 * x) * cos (20 * x)"
shows  "\<forall> x. sin (x/10) + sin (x/5) + sin (3*x/10) + sin (2*x/5) + sin (x/2) + sin (3*x/5) + sin (7*x/10) + sin (4*x/5) = 4 * sqrt 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given that $\sin(x) + \sin(2x) + \sin(3x) + \sin(4x) + \sin(5x) + \sin(6x) + \sin(7x) + \sin(8x) = 4\sqrt{2} \cos(5x) \cos(10x) \cos(20x)$, find the value of $\sin(x/10) + \sin(x/5) + \sin(3x/10) + \sin(2x/5) + \sin(x/2) + \sin(3x/5) + \sin(7x/10) + \sin(4x/5)$. The final answer is $4\sqrt{2}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80} \<longrightarrow> sin x \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {5, 10, 20} \<longrightarrow> cos x > 0"
and h2 : "(sum sin {10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80}) / (prod cos {5, 10, 20}) = 4 * sqrt 2"
shows  "4 * sqrt 2 = (sum sin {10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80}) / (prod cos {5, 10, 20})"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\frac{\sin 10^\circ + \sin 20^\circ + \sin 30^\circ + \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ + \sin 60^\circ + \sin 70^\circ + \sin 80^\circ}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\] The final Answer is 4 \sqrt{2}
 ### Proof
 By sum-to-product, \begin{align} \sin 10^\circ + \sin 80^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 35^\circ, \\ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 70^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 25^\circ, \\ \sin 30^\circ + \sin 60^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\
 \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the given expression becomes \[\frac{2 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 35^\circ + \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ + \cos 5^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\]Similarly, \begin{align}
 \cos 35^\circ + \cos 5^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\ \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the expression becomes \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ \cos 20^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ} = \frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ}.\]Finally, $\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ = 2 \cos 10^\circ \cos 5^\circ,$ so
 \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ} = 8 \sin 45^\circ = \boxed{4 \sqrt{2}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80} \<longrightarrow> sin x \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {5, 10, 20} \<longrightarrow> cos x > 0"
and h2 : "(sum sin {10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80}) / (prod cos {5, 10, 20}) = 4 * sqrt 2"
shows  "4 * sqrt 2 = (sum sin {10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80}) / (prod cos {5, 10, 20})"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: The sum of the sine of angles 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, and 80 degrees, all divided by the product of the cosine of angles 5, 10, and 20 degrees, equals $4\sqrt{2}$. Verify this equality.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. sin (n * 10) = sin (n * 10)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. cos (n * 5) = cos (n * 5)"
shows  "(sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80) / (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20) = 4 * sqrt 2"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\frac{\sin 10^\circ + \sin 20^\circ + \sin 30^\circ + \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ + \sin 60^\circ + \sin 70^\circ + \sin 80^\circ}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\] The final Answer is 4 \sqrt{2}
 ### Proof
 By sum-to-product, \begin{align} \sin 10^\circ + \sin 80^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 35^\circ, \\ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 70^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 25^\circ, \\ \sin 30^\circ + \sin 60^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\
 \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the given expression becomes \[\frac{2 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 35^\circ + \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ + \cos 5^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\]Similarly, \begin{align}
 \cos 35^\circ + \cos 5^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\ \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the expression becomes \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ \cos 20^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ} = \frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ}.\]Finally, $\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ = 2 \cos 10^\circ \cos 5^\circ,$ so
 \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ} = 8 \sin 45^\circ = \boxed{4 \sqrt{2}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. sin (n * 10) = sin (n * 10)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. cos (n * 5) = cos (n * 5)"
shows  "(sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80) / (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20) = 4 * sqrt 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Evaluate the expression $\frac{\sin(10) + \sin(20) + \sin(30) + \sin(40) + \sin(50) + \sin(60) + \sin(70) + \sin(80)}{\cos(5) \cdot \cos(10) \cdot \cos(20)}$. The final answer is $4\sqrt{2}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. sin x + sin (2 * x) + sin (3 * x) + sin (4 * x) + sin (5 * x) + sin (6 * x) + sin (7 * x) + sin (8 * x) = 4 * sqrt 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. cos (x / 2) * cos x * cos (2 * x) = 1"
shows  "sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80 / (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20) = 4 * sqrt 2"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\frac{\sin 10^\circ + \sin 20^\circ + \sin 30^\circ + \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ + \sin 60^\circ + \sin 70^\circ + \sin 80^\circ}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\] The final Answer is 4 \sqrt{2}
 ### Proof
 By sum-to-product, \begin{align} \sin 10^\circ + \sin 80^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 35^\circ, \\ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 70^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 25^\circ, \\ \sin 30^\circ + \sin 60^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\
 \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the given expression becomes \[\frac{2 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 35^\circ + \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ + \cos 5^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\]Similarly, \begin{align}
 \cos 35^\circ + \cos 5^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\ \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the expression becomes \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ \cos 20^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ} = \frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ}.\]Finally, $\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ = 2 \cos 10^\circ \cos 5^\circ,$ so
 \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ} = 8 \sin 45^\circ = \boxed{4 \sqrt{2}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. sin x + sin (2 * x) + sin (3 * x) + sin (4 * x) + sin (5 * x) + sin (6 * x) + sin (7 * x) + sin (8 * x) = 4 * sqrt 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. cos (x / 2) * cos x * cos (2 * x) = 1"
shows  "sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80 / (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20) = 4 * sqrt 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find an equation that satisfies both the condition that the sum of the sine of ten through eighty, increased by increments of ten, equals four times the square root of two, and the condition that the product of the cosine of five, ten, and twenty equals one. The final equation is $\frac{sin(10) + sin(20) + sin(30) + sin(40) + sin(50) + sin(60) + sin(70) + sin(80)}{cos(5) * cos(10) * cos(20)} = 4\sqrt{2}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = (sin (10 * pi / 180) + sin (20 * pi / 180) + sin (30 * pi / 180) + sin (40 * pi / 180) + sin (50 * pi / 180) + sin (60 * pi / 180) + sin (70 * pi / 180) + sin (80 * pi / 180)) / (cos (5 * pi / 180) * cos (10 * pi / 180) * cos (20 * pi / 180))"
shows  "x = 4 * sqrt 2"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\frac{\sin 10^\circ + \sin 20^\circ + \sin 30^\circ + \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ + \sin 60^\circ + \sin 70^\circ + \sin 80^\circ}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\] The final Answer is 4 \sqrt{2}
 ### Proof
 By sum-to-product, \begin{align} \sin 10^\circ + \sin 80^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 35^\circ, \\ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 70^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 25^\circ, \\ \sin 30^\circ + \sin 60^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\
 \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the given expression becomes \[\frac{2 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 35^\circ + \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ + \cos 5^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\]Similarly, \begin{align}
 \cos 35^\circ + \cos 5^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\ \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the expression becomes \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ \cos 20^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ} = \frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ}.\]Finally, $\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ = 2 \cos 10^\circ \cos 5^\circ,$ so
 \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ} = 8 \sin 45^\circ = \boxed{4 \sqrt{2}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = (sin (10 * pi / 180) + sin (20 * pi / 180) + sin (30 * pi / 180) + sin (40 * pi / 180) + sin (50 * pi / 180) + sin (60 * pi / 180) + sin (70 * pi / 180) + sin (80 * pi / 180)) / (cos (5 * pi / 180) * cos (10 * pi / 180) * cos (20 * pi / 180))"
shows  "x = 4 * sqrt 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the value of $x$ that satisfies the equation $x = \frac{\sin(10\pi/180) + \sin(20\pi/180) + \sin(30\pi/180) + \sin(40\pi/180) + \sin(50\pi/180) + \sin(60\pi/180) + \sin(70\pi/180) + \sin(80\pi/180)}{\cos(5\pi/180)\cos(10\pi/180)\cos(20\pi/180)}$. The final answer is $4\sqrt{2}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80 = 4 * sqrt 2 * (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20)"
shows  "sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80 = 4 * sqrt 2 * (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\frac{\sin 10^\circ + \sin 20^\circ + \sin 30^\circ + \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ + \sin 60^\circ + \sin 70^\circ + \sin 80^\circ}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\] The final Answer is 4 \sqrt{2}
 ### Proof

 \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the given expression becomes \[\frac{2 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 35^\circ + \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ + \cos 5^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\]Similarly, \begin{align}
 \cos 35^\circ + \cos 5^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\ \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the expression becomes \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ \cos 20^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ} = \frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ}.\]Finally, $\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ = 2 \cos 10^\circ \cos 5^\circ,$ so
 \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ} = 8 \sin 45^\circ = \boxed{4 \sqrt{2}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80 = 4 * sqrt 2 * (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20)"
shows  "sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80 = 4 * sqrt 2 * (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Show that the sum of the sine of 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, and 80 degrees is equal to 4 times the square root of 2 times the product of the cosine of 5, 10, and 20 degrees.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. (sin x)\<^sup>2 + (cos x)\<^sup>2 = 1"
and h1 : "sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80 = 4 * sqrt 2 * (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20)"
shows  "4 * sqrt 2 = (sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80) / (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\frac{\sin 10^\circ + \sin 20^\circ + \sin 30^\circ + \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ + \sin 60^\circ + \sin 70^\circ + \sin 80^\circ}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\] The final Answer is 4 \sqrt{2}
 ### Proof
 By sum-to-product, \begin{align} \sin 10^\circ + \sin 80^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 35^\circ, \\ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 70^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 25^\circ, \\ \sin 30^\circ + \sin 60^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\
 \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the given expression becomes \[\frac{2 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 35^\circ + \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ + \cos 5^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\]Similarly, \begin{align}
 \cos 35^\circ + \cos 5^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\ \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the expression becomes \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ \cos 20^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ} = \frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ}.\]Finally, $\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ = 2 \cos 10^\circ \cos 5^\circ,$ so
 \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ} = 8 \sin 45^\circ = \boxed{4 \sqrt{2}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. (sin x)\<^sup>2 + (cos x)\<^sup>2 = 1"
and h1 : "sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80 = 4 * sqrt 2 * (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20)"
shows  "4 * sqrt 2 = (sin 10 + sin 20 + sin 30 + sin 40 + sin 50 + sin 60 + sin 70 + sin 80) / (cos 5 * cos 10 * cos 20)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that for every real number $x$, the square of the sine of $x$ plus the square of the cosine of $x$ equals 1, and that the sum of the sines of 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, and 80 degrees equals $4\sqrt{2}$ times the product of the cosine of 5, 10 and 20 degrees. Show that $4\sqrt{2}$ equals the fraction of the sum of the sines of 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, and 80 degrees over the product of the cosine of 5, 10 and 20 degrees.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. - (pi / 2) \<le> x \<and> x \<le> pi / 2 \<longrightarrow> sin x = cos (pi / 2 - x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> pi / 2 \<longrightarrow> cos x = sqrt (1 - sin x powr 2)"
shows  "(sin (10*pi/180) + sin (20*pi/180) + sin (30*pi/180) + sin (40*pi/180) + sin (50*pi/180) + sin (60*pi/180) + sin (70*pi/180) + sin (80*pi/180)) / (cos (5*pi/180) * cos (10*pi/180) * cos (20*pi/180)) = 4 * sqrt 2"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\frac{\sin 10^\circ + \sin 20^\circ + \sin 30^\circ + \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ + \sin 60^\circ + \sin 70^\circ + \sin 80^\circ}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\] The final Answer is 4 \sqrt{2}
 ### Proof
 By sum-to-product, \begin{align} \sin 10^\circ + \sin 80^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 35^\circ, \\ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 70^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 25^\circ, \\ \sin 30^\circ + \sin 60^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\
 \sin 40^\circ + \sin 50^\circ &= 2 \sin 45^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the given expression becomes \[\frac{2 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 35^\circ + \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ + \cos 5^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ}.\]Similarly, \begin{align}
 \cos 35^\circ + \cos 5^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 15^\circ, \\ \cos 25^\circ + \cos 15^\circ &= 2 \cos 20^\circ \cos 5^\circ, \end{align}so the expression becomes \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ \cos 20^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ \cos 20^\circ} = \frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ}.\]Finally, $\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ = 2 \cos 10^\circ \cos 5^\circ,$ so
 \[\frac{4 \sin 45^\circ (\cos 5^\circ + \cos 15^\circ)}{\cos 5^\circ \cos 10^\circ} = 8 \sin 45^\circ = \boxed{4 \sqrt{2}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes sin cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. - (pi / 2) \<le> x \<and> x \<le> pi / 2 \<longrightarrow> sin x = cos (pi / 2 - x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> pi / 2 \<longrightarrow> cos x = sqrt (1 - sin x powr 2)"
shows  "(sin (10*pi/180) + sin (20*pi/180) + sin (30*pi/180) + sin (40*pi/180) + sin (50*pi/180) + sin (60*pi/180) + sin (70*pi/180) + sin (80*pi/180)) / (cos (5*pi/180) * cos (10*pi/180) * cos (20*pi/180)) = 4 * sqrt 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the value of $\frac{\sin(10\pi/180) + \sin(20\pi/180) + \sin(30\pi/180) + \sin(40\pi/180) + \sin(50\pi/180) + \sin(60\pi/180) + \sin(70\pi/180) + \sin(80\pi/180)}{\cos(5\pi/180) \cdot \cos(10\pi/180) \cdot \cos(20\pi/180)}$. The final answer is $4\sqrt{2}$.
